headline: Ohio Senate race in virtual deadlock: poll
author: Rachel Scully
sentences: While support for the candidates largely falls upon party lines, Ryan is trying to appeal to moderates in an attempt to take away more votes from Vance, as the GOP candidate struggled for much of the race to break out of the middle of the GOP primary pack.

While Ryan continues to run a moderate campaign, David Paleologos, director of Suffolk University's Political Research Center, said that he may lose some ground as many Ohio residents grow more frustrated with the economy and President Biden's leadership.

Many believe Biden will be a hurdle for Ryan, according to the new survey, as 49.4 percent of Ohio voters said they want their vote in November to change the direction in which Biden has led the country.
Here's Ryan trying to emerge from the quicksand  and he's getting drawn back into it because the problem of the economy is so ominous in Ohio, Paleologos said, according to the Cincinnati Enquirer.
The USA Today Network Ohio/Suffolk University survey released Wednesday found that Vance leads Ryan by just more than 2 percentage points among likely Ohio voters, well within the margin of error.
When former President Trump endorsed Vance in mid-April, the Republican candidate's popularity improved, with many seeing the endorsement as a key test of his strength within the GOP.
Additionally, 39.8 percent of respondents said they find Ryan more favorable, compared to the 34.6 who say the same about Vance.
The poll of 500 likely Ohio midterm voters, conducted between May 22-24, has a margin of error of 4 percentage points.
Almost 17 percent of respondents percent remain undecided in the closely watched race to replace retiring Sen.
Vance received the support of 41.6 percent of voters questioned compared to Ryan's 39.4 percent.
Vance and Rep. Tim Ryan (D) is in a virtual deadlock, according to a new poll.
